title: Cat Tracker reveals the unknown adventures of felines through GPS technology - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)

organizations.name: school of natural and built environments

text:
Map: Adelaide 5000 
How much does an owner know about their cat's clandestine adventures? According to new research from the University of South Australia, you might be in for a shock. 
Bagheera the cat spends most of her days accepting pats at an Adelaide high school where owner Louise Davy works as a teacher. 
But it was not until Ms Davy entered Bagheera into a South Australian research project that her nocturnal wanderings were revealed. 
"I was astonished about where he had gone. He roamed over 20 hectares " she said. 
It turned out Bagheera was also a regular night-time visitor to the neighbour's house, where an Australian native garden had a tempting supply of birds. 
"He was obviously going there in the night time, because they had never seen him," Ms Davy said. 
Bagheera is one of more than 400 cats whose owners strapped GPS units to their collars for a week as part of the University of South Australia's Cat Tracker project. 
Doctor Philip Roetman from the university's School of Natural and Built Environments said there was no other research like it in the world. 
"Previous studies have only tracked between 10 and 20 cats, so it has been fascinating to look at this really large sample of data" he said. Photo: Rusty the Cat from Mount Gambier has also been profiled, along with his GPS tracking data. (Supplied: Discovery Circle) 
Researchers found the median range cats were roaming was 1.04 hectares, which is approximately half the playing surface at the Adelaide Oval. 
It came as a shock to many owners — including one who sent their GPS cat tracker back to researchers with an apology note, saying their cat had barely left the house, and it had all been a waste of time. 
"But when we looked at the tracks of that cat it had a massive home range — one of the largest ones we looked at," Dr Philip Roetman said. 
He said many cats were having clandestine adventures despite their owners assuming they stayed indoors at night. 
"We found that roughly 40 per cent of the cats that were supposedly inside at night, actually had quite large ranges at night," he said. Five feline personality traits identified 
Researchers also identified five major personality factors for pet cats — skittishness, outgoingness, dominance, spontaneity and friendliness. 
They said the information could be used by owners to make decisions about how to manage their cat. 
"So, for example, if an owner has a particularly skittish cat, they might decide to provide extra hiding places for their pet, to make the cat more comfortable," Dr Roetman said. 
But that is not something Bagheera had to worry about. He scored high in friendliness and outgoingness. 
"He is really low in skittishness so he makes the perfect school cat," she said. 
Researchers also divided the cats into two main types, "sedentary" or "wandering". 
"Those wandering cats that go further, they show more signs of being in fights, they cross more roads, and they bring home more prey, typically," Dr Roetman said. Photo: Dr Philip Roetman demonstrates the GPS unit with his model cat, Willow. (ABC News: Ruby Jones) Wide support for a cat curfew 
Researchers also asked people about their attitudes to cats. They found widespread support for a cat curfew as well as for micro-chipping. 
"There was less support for cat registration, so that could be a tricky one," Dr Roetman said. 
Researchers are interested in launching a national Cat Tracker program and also want to look at cat diet to see if it has an influence on how far the cats wander. 
"I'm sure cat owners would love to know if what they are feeding their cat can influence their cat to stay closer to home," Dr Roetman said.
